website_summaries.verdict: This photo-based guide is well organized and useful for tree enthusiasts of all experience levels.
pros: More than 5,000 large, detailed photographs – many to scale
Keys let you narrow a tree down by family or genus, while Master Pages take you down further to specific identifications
Good for beginners to advanced nature lovers
cons: At 8 1/2" x 11", book is a little large to take into the field
The black and white photographs are not detailed enough

customer_reviews.title: Best ID book
customer_reviews.text: One of the best identification books I've found for landscape architecture in grad school. I found the Peterson guides confusing as you had to flip through multiple sections of the book to find information on the same plants or trees, but this one is quite clear. Best pictures and ID book I've found.
customer_reviews.author: Nadine

customer_reviews.title: it has black & white pictures - but they are large and show great detail. It is large (8-1/2" x 11") so ...
customer_reviews.text: Be aware, it has black & white pictures - but they are large and show great detail. It is large (8-1/2" x 11") so not a good size as a field guide while also carrying a camera, but it will still be a good resource for identification. Color photos would be more helpful as I am a visual person. Looking forward to using it once winter is over!
customer_reviews.author: JodyJ

customer_reviews.title: Easy to identify
customer_reviews.text: Great book. I checked it out of the library and liked it so much I ordered it for myself as reference. The photos are black and white but excellent reference and this book makes it easy to identify by leaf and blossoms and shape of tree. An oldy but a goody.
customer_reviews.author: jenny br

customer_reviews.title: Works good for an amature.
customer_reviews.text: This is my first and only tree identification book. I have read lots of reviews to pick this book. I am glad I did. I like that this done in normal (not pocket) size. The identification system of this book is pretty good-I have no problems using it. Thank you.
customer_reviews.author: Olja

customer_reviews.title: The best tree identification  book ever
customer_reviews.text: This book is completely comprehensive and a pictorial view of identification rather than a dichotomous key. So easy to use. I recommend this book to anyone who wants to have fun learning the art and science of identifying trees.
customer_reviews.author: Naturalist

customer_reviews.title: Best Picture ID book
customer_reviews.text: I have had 6 copies of this book each seems to disappear, I used to loan it out. It is just such an easy ID book you can't miss the ID. I especially like the buds and seeds sections great for no leaf ID.
customer_reviews.author: B

customer_reviews.title: There are better books available.
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this book, and it is easy to use, but not in color. I also own and have used other tree Identification books and this one is not worth it if you only want to purchase one. Currently I would suggest The Audubon Society Field Guide to North American Trees over this book, though it too has its limitations. May be best to buy and read them all but that is not practical.
customer_reviews.author: Mark

customer_reviews.title: An essential for the advanced tree lover
customer_reviews.text: Very good reference for the more educated of tree enthusiasts. Assists in tree ID through not only leaves but through bark, cones/fruits/seeds. Truly an essential for the tree lover.
customer_reviews.author: David Balla

customer_reviews.title: Black and white, don’t buy.
customer_reviews.text: It’s black and white!! A tree identification book that uses images to help identify colorful trees that may may in shade and such that is Black and White!!! Terrible.
customer_reviews.author: scott presley

customer_reviews.title: If you have to get it, get the non-kindle version
customer_reviews.text: Don't get the Kindle version. You really need to be able to flip pages because there's no true (dichotomous) key. I've had it for two years now and every now and then try again to use it and give up. In the meantime, I've found a few other books (none of them Kindle). Can't recommend any single one because it takes two or three to find what you need to identify, recognize and understand a tree.
customer_reviews.author: OneIsTwo

customer_reviews.title: Mostly poorly printed black & white photos.
customer_reviews.text: Poorly printed black and white photos. Some of the bark photos are so overexposed you can’t see any details beyond the outline of the tree. Many photos are so bad they look like they were printed on a xerox machine at the public library, where someone forgot to close the lid on the machine.
customer_reviews.author: Katie

customer_reviews.title: This tree book carried what I was looking for, the other one didnot.
customer_reviews.text: This book had the Hat-ma-tac tree I was looking for, Paterson's did not.
customer_reviews.author: Lttle Dove

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Very nice, layed out well and pictures are nice quality.
customer_reviews.author: Tony

customer_reviews.title: This is a wonderful tool to identify trees
customer_reviews.text: We were reluctant to purchase this as the photo's are all in black and white, but found that it did not really matter because the photos of the leaves and tree bark are very large and clear. This is a wonderful tool to identify trees.
customer_reviews.author: sk

customer_reviews.title: All black & white but still a great addition to my collection of tree identification books.  I would recommend this book.
customer_reviews.text: Sometimes you need many tree books to come up with proper identification. This is definitely an addition to my collection. It approaches in a different way. All black & white but good multiple indications of leaves from same tree. I am glad I purchased it & would recommend it.
customer_reviews.author: J Whitmer

customer_reviews.title: Useless
customer_reviews.text: No useful information. Couldn’t find my trees or anything like them
customer_reviews.author: Janette Cano

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: One of the best tree identification books you can own--identify from twigs, leaves, bark, even in winter. Great book.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: It's all in the details
customer_reviews.text: Symonds has created an excellent reference for any time of the year. Great for any age- I used it for myself extensively and then with my students who were not experienced in identification. These books did not intimidate my students and they quickly were teaching each other how to use them.
customer_reviews.author: Jennifer L Ault

customer_reviews.title: Very useful book.
customer_reviews.text: Glad I purchased this book as a gift. The person who received the book really likes it and more importantly will use it.
customer_reviews.author: Anita S.

customer_reviews.title: Tree ID, this is it!
customer_reviews.text: Excellent resource book. Pictures are great. We'll put together. Easy to follow. I have quite a few tree identification books and this is by far the better of all of them. If you want/need a good book for tree ID, look no further.
customer_reviews.author: Adam McDuff

customer_reviews.title: Best tree identification source I've ever used
customer_reviews.text: Best tree identification source I've ever used. Carry it with you when there are leaves on the trees, and you'll quickly identify a bunch of trees.
customer_reviews.author: Slow Joe

customer_reviews.title: This book breaks down trees so that you can use ...
customer_reviews.text: This book breaks down trees so that you can use anything from bark to fruit to find what tree you are looking at
customer_reviews.author: Jake

customer_reviews.title: Good reference for Tree ID
customer_reviews.text: Good identification book, more color would help (but would raise the excellent price).
customer_reviews.author: Charles R. Andre

customer_reviews.title: An easy sytem to help with identification.
customer_reviews.text: Very cool the identification system. You can id a tree by looking at leaves or flowers or seeds, etc. Much better than some other book that list the species, but do not provide a means to id positively.
customer_reviews.author: DA

customer_reviews.title: The book is good, but I wish it was a little more ...
customer_reviews.text: The book is good, but I wish it was a little more detailed. With that said, I will keep it. I have identified quite a few trees on my Georgia property.
customer_reviews.author: DCK

customer_reviews.title: Lots and lots of illustrations
customer_reviews.text: Book in perfect shape. Very interesting illustrations placed in juxtaposition to similar to highlight differences for identification.
customer_reviews.author: Kit-Ten

customer_reviews.title: I knew I had an oak tree but this book ...
customer_reviews.text: I knew I had an oak tree but this book helped me ID it by the leaf features. Now my first go to book for identification.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Tree ID Guide
customer_reviews.text: This book offeres exactly what it states; a Practical Identification. I work for the USFS and find this book to be a great resource to my collection. It doesn't contain all tree species but certainly does have the most common/abundant species. Providing detailed black and white photo's (of great quality) identification can be based on flowers, leaves, bark, and leaf scars. Most books that I have come across don't have pictures of all these, but this book does. The more information you can gather and compare to a photo, the more accurate you're ID will be. Always pack this in my bag for a day of field work-a great purchase.
customer_reviews.author: julianR

customer_reviews.title: Tree Identification Book: A New Method for the Practical Identification of Trees
customer_reviews.text: I purchased this book while I was a horticulture student. I now own many tree ID books, but this remains the best of the lot. It is so easy and quick to use that I can find items faster than any of my other books. It was invaluable when I was preparing for a US-wide competition on woody plant ID. I live in the upper Midwest and most of the book is applicable to this part of the country. I am now buying a new copy, as my old one is a little tattered.
customer_reviews.author: Elizabeth S.

customer_reviews.title: Trees all over.
customer_reviews.text: This book goes deep into tree identification -- thorns, leaves, flowers, fruit, bark and needle. Large black and white pictures help. Take this book into the park/woods with you. I especially like the Oak Tree and the illustrations showing the associated acorns.
customer_reviews.author: pat

customer_reviews.title: Like it
customer_reviews.text: I bought this for a gift for my adventurous boyfriend. It was bigger than I thought it would be, but it's just what he wanted, detailed and with pictures. I was a little disappointed that it wasn't colored though.
customer_reviews.author: Crr

customer_reviews.title: great for desk reference
customer_reviews.text: this book is huge and not very sturdy. I wouldnt recommend it as a field guide. However, its a great reference. Every since I picked it up i have been doing much better in my dendrology labs. The pictures of the twigs, fruits and leaves are life sized, which helps alot. Too bad its not color! Hopefully, someday they will come out with a more durable, color version.
customer_reviews.author: Doris P. Fell

customer_reviews.title: Three Stars
customer_reviews.text: Book a little confusing. When you look up something in index it is not on the page it says
customer_reviews.author: Tammy Edwards

customer_reviews.title: Tree Identification Book
customer_reviews.text: I wanted a book that would help me identify trees with or without their leaves on. A landscape architect reccomended this book to me and it has been very handy. It's an older book and not in color, but still a great resource.
customer_reviews.author: Martin C. Howden

customer_reviews.title: WOW!
customer_reviews.text: Wonderful book. My grand daughter and I had the " Summer of the Trees" . This book plus another were our Bibles. It is a great and easy book to use to identify trees.
customer_reviews.author: DrSFS

customer_reviews.title: A must for field identification
customer_reviews.text: I use this book all of the time and work professionally in the field. The photographs and comparative keys are very easy to use. I've had this and the shrub companion in my pack for almost 20 years!
customer_reviews.author: Tony

customer_reviews.title: Photos make ID east
customer_reviews.text: "Trees of North America" has excellent illustrations organized / grouped with species most similar making comparisons and distinctions easy without turning back and forth between pages. The font is a bit small for aging eyes but photographs of vegetative and reproductive structures are great. This is a repurchase of an old friend for me - I used this book for years in teaching and I guess students found it valuable enough that my copy disappeared, actually more than once. HBR
customer_reviews.author: HBR

customer_reviews.title: A different approach to tree identification
customer_reviews.text: This book does not have an exhaustive list of tree species, but the diagrams and categories for identifying trees are useful once you get used to the new methodology.
customer_reviews.author: kc

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: Useful inexpensive field identification guide. Use it for wetland work.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: A useful system for tree identification
customer_reviews.text: This book has a helpful system for identifying trees and good photographs. My only complaint is that I would have loved a comprehensive index.
customer_reviews.author: Judith A. Parker

customer_reviews.title: Tree Identification Book : A New Method for the Practical Identification and Recognition of Trees
customer_reviews.text: This is a great picture tree identification book that lets you ID a tree relatively easily. Very user friendly. Even though photos are in black and white, they are very clear in most cases.
customer_reviews.author: JC

customer_reviews.title: perfect way to identify trees
customer_reviews.text: The "decision tree" process used in the book makes identifying any tree easy as pie. Very helpful as the leaves are pictures in their actual size
customer_reviews.author: Fen Wick

customer_reviews.title: Good reference book
customer_reviews.text: Have a new place with lots of trees on the property, need to identify the ones I need to keep.
customer_reviews.author: hoseverdie

customer_reviews.title: Four Stars
customer_reviews.text: Just received this manual and have been impressed about it's leading a novice along the path of tree identification.
customer_reviews.author: Dennis of Derby

customer_reviews.title: great detail
customer_reviews.text: This is an excellent book for personal library! It carries easily so it can be taken to the field. I'd buy again.
customer_reviews.author: sherri

customer_reviews.title: Good reference!
customer_reviews.text: Good reference to add to the library! Can't wait till next season to put it to practical use! Nicely laid out.
customer_reviews.author: Earl

customer_reviews.title: Excellent info, pictures a little dated
customer_reviews.text: The black and white photos can be a little tricky to make out but not bad. The set-up of the book makes it worth the buy. I would buy it again.
customer_reviews.author: T. Turner

customer_reviews.title: Perfect for what I was looking for
customer_reviews.text: All of the trees, I was looking to identify were found in this book. Great resource. I will keep this on my book shelf for a long time.
customer_reviews.author: Mardi Warner

customer_reviews.title: Incorrect Title
customer_reviews.text: Lots of people live in the Western U.S. All the trees mentioned in this book are in the East. True, some grow everywhere, but I was interested in Western trees. Now I must purchase another book. It's fine to be interested In where you live, but I feel a little frustrated when half the country is ignored, and no one thinks that is important enough to mention.
customer_reviews.author: Caroline Summersett

customer_reviews.title: that turned out to be my fault -I didn't look at the fine print. Fortunately
customer_reviews.text: I was a bit dismayed with the condition of the book on its arrival, however, that turned out to be my fault -I didn't look at the fine print. Fortunately, for me, all the pages were accounted for and no information was obscured, so sheet protectors from Costco did the trick. The book itself is invaluable -especially if you are an artist (like me), or a botanist, or even planning a career in forestry.
customer_reviews.author: Kaycee Kendall

customer_reviews.title: GREAT GUIDE!
customer_reviews.text: Easy to read, easy to follow ..... this one will be the one to keep ..... this is our first tree guide, and after reading other reviews, we have to agree it is great for the novice.
customer_reviews.author: sjb

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: I love the organization of this book. It has really assisted in developing my skills for tree identification.
customer_reviews.author: Jan

customer_reviews.title: Four Stars
customer_reviews.text: A tried and true reference when trying to identify a particular tree.
customer_reviews.author: Eva Klatt

customer_reviews.title: FIND A BETTER BOOK
customer_reviews.text: ITS NOT AS EASY TO USE AS THE DISCRIPTION STATES. IT DOES CONTAIN ALOT OF GOOD INFORMATION. THE PICTURES ARE BLACK AND WHITE AND THE WORLD AROUND US IS COLOR. THIS BOOK HAS BEEN HELPFULL BUT I STILL HAVE A TREE IN MY YARD THAT I AM UNABLE TO IDENTIFY
customer_reviews.author: Ty

customer_reviews.title: Five Stars
customer_reviews.text: The book is so informative for when I do tree inspections, a real helper.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: The Tree Identification Book by George W. D. Symonds
customer_reviews.text: Excellent resource book for anyone seeking to identify trees by their leaves, bark, flowers, fruit, twigs, buds or thorns. Even though the photos are in black and white, their 3-dimensional appearance helps very much in identifying a tree.
customer_reviews.author: Y. M. Baldwin

customer_reviews.title: Great to book to identify trees!
customer_reviews.text: This book is great to have for those who are interested in identifying trees in the eastern US. One might initially think that black-and-white photos wouldn't be effective tools, but they are perfect!! I highly recommend this book. It is very detail and easy to identify all tress I have on my property!
customer_reviews.author: Justin H

customer_reviews.title: Surprised.
customer_reviews.text: I was disappointed to find the pictures were in black and white, however after looking thrugh the book, I think color photos are not necessary, color would have been distracting and too expensive. Now I see that black and white shows the details I will need more easily. I think I will like the book more as I use it.
customer_reviews.author: MaryCay

customer_reviews.title: Great shape!
customer_reviews.text: I received the book that I requested. It is in great, new condition. I have no complaints and I would order from this company again.
customer_reviews.author: Amy

customer_reviews.title: Great reference book
customer_reviews.text: This is a great book for the novice of tree research. I use it very frequently and find it very accurate.
customer_reviews.author: Neil Scheidt

customer_reviews.title: but they are perfect!! I highly recommend this book as well ...
customer_reviews.text: This book is a must have for those who are interested in identifying trees in the eastern US. One might initially think that black-and-white photos wouldn't be effective tools, but they are perfect!! I highly recommend this book as well as the shrub ID book.
customer_reviews.author: Rebecca

customer_reviews.title: Photos are bad
customer_reviews.text: The weak photos really ruin and devalue the book. They made the task of identification a real hornets nest to unravel.
customer_reviews.author: Michael

customer_reviews.title: Pretty much all you can do with this book is ...
customer_reviews.text: You've got to be kidding? I'm sorry, but this book is a "fail". I own an extensive collection of field guides and was wanting to "boost" my tree identification library after struggling to identify a Ninebark. (which I accomplished, finally, using Peterson's Field Guide) I never would have found it with this book. Pretty much all you can do with this book is scan through the black and white photos and hope you can stumble upon your specimen - and it better not be something just a little unusual. There are too many good tree identification resources out there to settle for this dud.
customer_reviews.author: Michael Geske

customer_reviews.title: only some specific trees.
customer_reviews.text: It identifies some trees sure...but only specific ones and There are many not listed.
customer_reviews.author: alex m.

customer_reviews.title: Detailed Tree ID
customer_reviews.text: All black & white WITH detailed descriptions. Could use color and clearer illustrations.
customer_reviews.author: John Dorosky

customer_reviews.title: One Star
customer_reviews.text: I never received this book. I'm still waiting for it.
customer_reviews.author: Amazon Customer

customer_reviews.title: Great beginners' tree id book.
customer_reviews.text: Retired neighbors are looking forward to spring to ID their new property woodlands. This book compares side by side plain pics to clearly show differences in trees. They really like it!
customer_reviews.author: Nanalin

product_meta.title: Tree Identification Book : A New Method for the Practical Identification and Recognition of Trees
